instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the open source Semi-Automatic Landslide Detection (SALaD) system?
Output: The related study used visible and nir remote sensing spectrum in the open source Semi-Automatic Landslide Detection (SALaD) system.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the open source Semi-Automatic Landslide Detection (SALaD) system?
Output: The spectral features used in the SALaD system were normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) and brightness.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the open source Semi-Automatic Landslide Detection (SALaD) system and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the SALaD system was accuracy, which was reported to be 70% compared to manual inventory when specifically looking at landslide area. The accuracy metric can provide a general assessment of the system's performance but may not capture all nuances or specific details of landslide detection.

instruction: What machine learning techniques were utilized in the open source Semi-Automatic Landslide Detection (SALaD) system?
Output: Random Forests and Support Vector Machine were utilized in the open source Semi-Automatic Landslide Detection (SALaD) system.

instruction: Can the open source Semi-Automatic Landslide Detection (SALaD) system utilizing object-based image analysis (OBIA) and machine learning be considered superior to traditional manual techniques for mapping landslides over large areas?
Output: Yes, the open source Semi-Automatic Landslide Detection (SALaD) system utilizing object-based image analysis (OBIA) and machine learning can be considered superior to traditional manual techniques for mapping landslides over large areas. The system was tested in a 575 km(2) area along the Pasang Lhamu Highway in Nepal, where a large number of landslides were triggered by the 2015 Gorkha earthquake. The comparison with a manual inventory showed that the system was able to detect 70% of the landslide area. Additionally, the speed and efficiency of the system in detecting landslides make it a viable alternative to manual techniques when establishing approximate landslide locations is of prime importance.
